instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.GPUVCORE_EN: What is GPUVCORE_EN? GPUVCORE_EN enables GPU VCORE when it is high, a power rail necessary for the GPU to function so you can get an image on the screen. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No GPU Vcore
threads.message:
Hi,

I have that <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with a previous repair attempt on <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>. The rest of the board looks clean, no corrosion.
<CHIP>U8900</CHIP> area looked pretty bad so I have decided to rebuild it swapping all the nasty components.
I did also swap <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> from a donor board.

Once powered on, I could hear something clicking. It was <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>.
I have now removed it, checked for short and put another in place.

Board is turning on, chime, will respond to PRAM but no GPUVcore whatsoever.
I've double checked every resistor around <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and they all measure fine.

I am missing the enable signal on pin38 coming from the GMux chip.
So I am now confused in where to start. Should I be getting an enable signal even if <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is bad or not?
It's not even pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No GPU Vcore
threads.message: Check the GPU Power Sequence on page 88.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No GPU Vcore
threads.message: Iam getting none of the 5 enable signals on page 88

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No GPU Vcore
threads.message:
Check if <CHIP>U9100</CHIP> gets all voltages first.
Next, check for corrosion on its area and reflow with quality flux (no chinese honey).
Replace GMUX if needed.

Just in case, check is something change connecting external monitor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No GPU Vcore
threads.message:
My bad... using an oscilloscope, I can very briefly see them all showing up for some milliseconds then down to 0V, so does <SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_EN</SIGNAL>.
However <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> goes up to 200mV and then drops to 0V.

Resistance to ground <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> is 22ohms which seems ok.

Could it still be a bad ISL area (ISL itself has been replaced 3 times) or does sound more like a GMUX issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No GPU Vcore
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> pulses, I think more about bad GPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No GPU Vcore
